title: Grandma's Banana Bread: The Recipe Card I'll Never Lose
excerpt: A handwritten recipe card, four ripe bananas, and decades of family memories. This is my grandmother's banana bread ‚Äî the one that made the whole house smell like home.

body.text: Some recipes live in cookbooks. Some live on Pinterest boards you'll never scroll back to. And some live on a single handwritten recipe card that's been passed around so many times the edges are soft and the ink is starting to fade. My grandmother's banana bread is that last one.

The card says "Recipe from the kitchen of Mom" across the top. That's it. No blog post, no nutritional breakdown, no step-by-step photos. Just her handwriting, a list of ingredients, and "Bake at 350 for 1 hour" at the bottom. And honestly, that's all you need.
The Recipe Card

I love that this recipe fits on a single index card. There's something about that era of cooking ‚Äî no measurements down to the gram, no fussy techniques, no "if you don't use European-style butter this won't work." It's the kind of recipe that assumes you know your way around a kitchen, or that you'll figure it out. Four bananas, mash them. Three eggs, beat them. Mix it all together and put it in the oven. Done.

The genius is in its simplicity. There's no creaming butter and sugar for exactly four minutes. No folding in egg whites. You mash, you mix, you bake. And what comes out is better than anything I've ever found in a bakery case. Every single time.
Why It Works

If you look at the ingredient list, you'll notice a few things. First ‚Äî two cups of sugar and four bananas. That's a lot of sweetness, and it's not apologizing for it. This is not a "healthy banana bread" or a "refined sugar-free" version. This is the real thing. The kind of banana bread that tastes like banana bread is supposed to taste.

Second ‚Äî the milk mixed with two tablespoons of vinegar. That's an old-school move to make a buttermilk substitute. If you've never done it, you just stir the vinegar into the milk and let it sit for a few minutes. It curdles slightly, gets tangy, and does the same job as buttermilk in the batter. It makes the bread tender and gives it that subtle tang underneath all the sweetness.

Third ‚Äî the nuts. A cup of chopped nuts is non-negotiable in this recipe. My grandmother used walnuts. You could use pecans. But you don't skip them. They give every bite some texture and keep it from being one-note.
The Way I Make It

I follow the card almost exactly. The only thing I've changed over the years is using butter instead of margarine, because that's what I keep in the house. The card says "margarine or butter" ‚Äî my grandmother was practical like that. Use what you've got.

I let the bananas get really ripe. Like, the kind of ripe where you'd normally throw them away. Black-spotted, soft, almost liquid when you mash them. That's when they're perfect for this. The riper they are, the sweeter and more flavorful the bread turns out.

I sift the flour with the baking soda like the card says. I beat the eggs before adding them. I don't overthink it. The batter comes together in about ten minutes, goes into a greased loaf pan, and then the house smells incredible for the next hour.
More Than Just Bread

Here's the thing about a recipe like this ‚Äî it's never really about the bread. It's about standing in my grandmother's kitchen watching her mash bananas with a fork. It's about the smell hitting you when you walked through the front door. It's about the fact that she never once looked at the card while she made it, but she kept it in her recipe box anyway, just in case someone asked for it.

Now I'm the one people ask. And I pull out that same card ‚Äî her handwriting, her measurements, her "bake at 350 for 1 hour." I make it for my family the same way she made it for hers. My kids know it as "the banana bread," like there's only one version that matters. And honestly, there is.
Just Make It

If you've got bananas going brown on your counter, this is your sign. Don't throw them away and don't freeze them "for later." Just make the bread. It takes ten minutes to mix and an hour to bake. You probably have everything else in your pantry already. And when it comes out of the oven and you cut into it while it's still warm and the whole kitchen smells like your grandmother's house ‚Äî you'll understand why a little index card can be worth more than any cookbook.

title: Next Up: The Kokopelli Olympic Triathlon
excerpt: I've done a sprint. Now it's time to see what I'm capable of. The Kokopelli Olympic Triathlon in September is the next step ‚Äî here's why I picked it and what's ahead.

body.text: I did a sprint triathlon. It was hard, it was humbling, and I loved it. So naturally, the next question was ‚Äî can I go further? The answer is I don't know. But I'm going to find out.

The Kokopelli Olympic Triathlon in Hurricane, Utah on September 26 is the goal. That's a 1,500 meter swim, a 20.7 mile bike, and a 6.2 mile run. Roughly double the sprint distance across the board. It's a real step up, and I'd be lying if I said I wasn't nervous about it.

But that's the point of this whole thing. Average and active means pushing into uncomfortable territory ‚Äî not recklessly, but intentionally. I want to see what this body can do when I put in the work.
Why Kokopelli
I spent a while looking at races and this one checked every box.

**It's drivable.** I can pack my bike in the car, load up the family, and road trip out to Utah. No flying with a bike box, no shipping logistics, no stress about gear arriving in one piece. Just load up and go.
**Lower elevation.** Sand Hollow Reservoir sits at about 3,000 feet. Coming from Colorado, that's a gift. Training at elevation and racing lower is the advantage I'll take wherever I can get it.

**The timing works.** Race day is late September, which gives me a full training block starting April 1. That's roughly six months of focused preparation. Enough time to build properly without rushing it.

**Family trip built in.** This was a big factor. Zion National Park is 30 minutes away. Bryce Canyon is a couple hours out. The Grand Canyon North Rim is within driving distance. Sand Hollow State Park itself has beaches and paddleboarding ‚Äî the kids are going to lose their minds. This isn't just a race weekend, it's a family trip that happens to have a triathlon in the middle of it.

**It's beautiful.** Sand Hollow Reservoir is turquoise water surrounded by red Navajo sandstone. The swim goes through crystal-clear water with red rock islands breaking the surface. The bike and run courses overlook the reservoir the entire way. If I'm going to suffer for a few hours, at least the views will be worth it.
What I'm Worried About

**The heat.** September in southern Utah means race morning starts in the mid-60s but climbs into the mid-80s or higher by the time I'm on the run. The desert sun is intense, there's minimal shade on the course, and the humidity is low ‚Äî which sounds nice until you realize you're dehydrating faster than you think. Hydration strategy is going to be a big part of the training plan.

**The swim.** 1,500 meters in open water is a different animal than 750. Historically, the water temperature at Sand Hollow in late September hovers around 77-78 degrees ‚Äî right on the edge of wetsuit legal. The race director measures it at packet pickup and makes the call. I'm hoping it's wetsuit legal because the added buoyancy helps, but I need to train for both scenarios. The race has a Care Cap program for athletes who are nervous in open water ‚Äî I respect that they offer it, and honestly, doubling my swim distance in a reservoir is going to require some mental prep.

**The bike.** The course has about 791 feet of climbing over 20.7 miles. It's an out-and-back along Sand Hollow Road, which means whatever you climb going out, you get back coming in. There's a decent hill that's going to test the legs, especially knowing a 10K run comes after. Fun.
The Plan
Training kicks up on April 1. Between now and then, I'm in recovery mode, building my base back up, and staying consistent with the fundamentals ‚Äî zone 2 cardio, strength work, mobility.

Once April hits, the structured training begins. I'll be following a plan that builds volume gradually across all three disciplines. The swim needs the most work. The bike is where I feel strongest. The run is where I'll need to be smart about pacing, especially in the heat.

I'm going to post the whole journey. The training weeks, the brick workouts, the open water swims that scare me, the long rides, the days where it clicks and the days where it doesn't. The good and the bad. That's what average and active is about ‚Äî showing the real process, not just the finish line photo.
Why This Matters

Triathlon has a reputation for being an elite sport. Expensive gear, perfect bodies, Ironman bumper stickers. And sure, that world exists. But so does the world where a dad with a desk job decides to see what he's capable of. Where the goal isn't a podium finish ‚Äî it's crossing the line and knowing you earned it.

I have no idea what my time will be. I have no idea if race day will go perfectly or fall apart. But I know that six months from now, I'll be standing at Sand Hollow Reservoir at sunrise, looking at that turquoise water against the red rock, and I'll be ready to find out.
September 26. Kokopelli. Let's go.

title: Recovery Week: The Science Behind Slowing Down
excerpt: Taking a week off to recover from nagging injuries. Here's every tool I'm using and the science that backs each one.

body.text: I'm taking this week off from training. Not because I want to ‚Äî because I need to. Nagging injuries have been piling up, and ignoring them hasn't made them go away. Shocking, I know.

But here's the thing ‚Äî recovery isn't sitting on the couch doing nothing. That's actually one of the worst things you can do. Research shows that active recovery, where you keep moving at low intensity, outperforms complete rest for almost every type of injury. A study on runners found that active recovery helped them run three times longer in their next session compared to those who just sat around.
So this week, I'm still putting in work. It just looks different. Here's everything I'm doing and why the science says it matters.
Sauna

This is the recovery tool with the most impressive research behind it. The big study comes from Finland ‚Äî Dr. Jari Laukkanen followed over 2,000 men for 20 years and found that guys who used the sauna 4-7 times per week had 40% lower all-cause mortality compared to once-a-week users. Sessions longer than 19 minutes were linked to a 50% reduction in cardiac death.

The mechanism is heat shock proteins. When your body temperature rises, your cells produce these proteins that repair damaged proteins, reduce inflammation, and improve cellular resilience. Think of it as a stress test for your cells ‚Äî they come back stronger. Dr. Rhonda Patrick published a paper in Experimental Gerontology calling sauna use "a lifestyle practice to extend healthspan," and the data backs her up.

I'm hitting the sauna daily this week, 20-30 minutes per session. The research says that's the sweet spot for cardiovascular and recovery benefits. I make sure to hydrate before and after ‚Äî dehydration is the main risk with regular sauna use.
Red Light Therapy

Red light therapy, or photobiomodulation, uses specific wavelengths of light (660nm red and 810-850nm near-infrared) that your mitochondria absorb. The light hits an enzyme called cytochrome c oxidase in your cells, which boosts ATP production ‚Äî basically giving your cells more energy to repair themselves.

The research here is promising but still developing. A meta-analysis of 28 studies found overall benefits for muscle performance and recovery. What's interesting is that applying red light before exercise (40-60 minutes prior) seems to reduce muscle damage markers and inflammation. Studies on volleyball players showed reduced creatine kinase markers with benefits lasting 72-96 hours after treatment.

I use my red light panel for about 10-15 minutes, focusing on the areas that are bothering me most. The science shows there's a sweet spot with dosing ‚Äî too little does nothing, too much can actually be counterproductive. Start conservative and build up.
Stretching

Here's where the science might surprise you. A 2025 Delphi consensus statement from international researchers concluded that stretching is "largely inefficient as a post-exercise recovery strategy." It doesn't prevent soreness and it doesn't significantly speed up recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage.

But that doesn't mean it's useless. Static stretching is effective for increasing range of motion ‚Äî 15-30 seconds per hold is enough to see gains. And for specific injuries, especially hamstring strains, more intensive stretching protocols actually help athletes recover faster. Slow dynamic stretching, where you move through the stretch at a controlled pace, is showing some of the best results for maintaining mobility without the downsides of long static holds.

During recovery week, I'm doing 15-20 minutes of slow dynamic stretching daily. Not because it's going to fix my injuries overnight, but because maintaining range of motion keeps everything else working properly. I focus on the areas that get tight from training ‚Äî hips, shoulders, and ankles.
Massage Gun

I use the massage gun more during recovery weeks than any other time. The research says it's best for reducing perceived soreness and improving flexibility rather than enhancing force production. A systematic review found that single applications of percussion therapy showed acute increases in flexibility, while multiple treatments reduced musculoskeletal pain.

A 2025 study published in Frontiers showed that percussion massage therapy effectively reduces muscle tone and hardness after exercise-induced fatigue, and helps recover muscle strength within 48 hours. The key takeaway ‚Äî one quick session isn't enough. The research shows better results when you use it immediately after exercise AND at 24, 48, and 72-hour intervals.

I spend about 2 minutes per muscle group, focusing on whatever feels tight or restricted. Moderate pressure ‚Äî let the gun do the work instead of digging in. I avoid bony areas and anything that feels sharp or inflamed.
Compression Boots

The Hyperice Normatec boots are one of my favorite recovery tools this week. They use sequential pneumatic compression ‚Äî inflating from your feet up to your hips in a wave pattern ‚Äî to push blood and lymphatic fluid back through your system. Your lymphatic system has no pump of its own, so this mechanical assist does work your body can't do as efficiently on its own.

The research backs up what you feel when you use them. A study found a 402% increase in popliteal artery blood flow during compression, and another showed a 42% increase in oxygenated hemoglobin in the Normatec group versus controls. That's significantly more oxygen and nutrients getting to damaged tissue. Research from the US Olympic Training Center by William Sands found that the boots increased pressure-to-pain thresholds in elite athletes after aggressive training and improved acute range of motion.

The most comprehensive meta-analysis to date ‚Äî Maia et al. in 2024, covering 17 studies and 319 athletes ‚Äî found a consistent reduction in perceived muscle soreness, particularly at the 48-hour mark post-exercise. Where the science gets honest is on the objective side ‚Äî the boots don't reliably reduce creatine kinase or other muscle damage markers, and they're roughly comparable to active recovery for clearing lactate. They won't replace sleep, nutrition, and time. But for reducing soreness and enhancing blood flow while you sit and recover, they're legit.

I'm using them for 20-30 minutes daily, usually while I catch up on reading or a show. Pressure around 80-100 mmHg, which is what most of the research used. The best part about compression boots during a recovery week is that they work while you do nothing ‚Äî passive recovery that's actually doing something under the surface.
Band Work

Resistance bands are underrated for recovery. The research here is strong, especially for rehabilitation. A systematic review and meta-analysis found that elastic resistance provides similar strength gains compared to conventional resistance devices like free weights and machines. That was surprising to me.

The beauty of bands during a recovery week is low-load sufficiency. Research shows that joint stability can be achieved with contractions as low as 25% of maximal effort, and muscle efficiency improves at 30-40% effort. Since stabilizer muscles are predominantly slow-twitch fibers, lower loads with higher reps are actually the ideal stimulus. A study on ankle instability found that six weeks of elastic band exercises increased both strength AND joint position sense.

I'm doing light band work daily ‚Äî shoulder rotations, lateral walks, pull-aparts, ankle stability exercises. 15-25 reps, 2-3 sets, nothing that approaches failure. The goal is blood flow, joint stability, and maintaining movement patterns without loading the areas that need rest.
Standing While Working

I work a desk job. Most of us do. And the research on prolonged sitting is rough ‚Äî a meta-analysis of 18 studies covering nearly 800,000 people found that sedentary behavior increases type 2 diabetes risk independent of how much you exercise. You can't out-train eight hours of sitting.

Standing desks help. One study showed a 23% improvement in insulin resistance after six months of standing desk use. Another found that standing for 180 minutes after lunch reduced blood sugar spikes by 43% compared to sitting. A Mayo Clinic study of over 7,000 adults found that men standing for at least 6 hours daily had a 59% reduced likelihood of obesity.

The key is alternating. Stand for 30-40 minutes, sit for 20-30 minutes. Research shows that exclusively standing all day causes its own problems ‚Äî leg swelling, varicose veins, lower back pain. The sweet spot is replacing 2-4 hours of daily sitting with standing, combined with regular movement breaks.
This week I'm being more intentional about standing during calls and switching positions throughout the day.
Walking

Walking might be the single best recovery tool that exists, and it costs nothing. A UC San Diego study found that just 20 minutes of moderate walking produces measurable anti-inflammatory effects ‚Äî a 5% decrease in immune cells producing TNF-alpha, a key inflammatory marker. That's from one session.

The chronic benefits are even better. Regular walking (30-60 minutes, 3-5 times per week) significantly lowers BMI and C-reactive protein, a major marker of systemic inflammation. Walking increases blood flow, promotes angiogenesis (new blood vessel growth), improves nutrient delivery to damaged tissues, and supports lymphatic drainage.

I'm walking 30-40 minutes every day this week. Usually with the dog, sometimes with the kids. The pace matters ‚Äî brisk enough that you're breathing a bit harder but can still have a conversation. That's the intensity where you get the anti-inflammatory benefits without adding training stress to your body.
Keep Moving

The old-school approach to injury was RICE ‚Äî rest, ice, compress, elevate. The modern approach has shifted toward controlled activity. Complete rest leads to muscle atrophy, reduced blood flow, joint stiffness, and slower healing. A study on muscle fatigue showed that muscles recovered to pre-exercise values only after active recovery, while passive rest actually left fatigue markers elevated above baseline.

Active recovery works because it increases blood flow, which accelerates waste removal and delivers oxygen and nutrients to healing tissues. It keeps joints lubricated with synovial fluid. It prevents the deconditioning that makes coming back from injury harder than the injury itself.

The rule is simple ‚Äî stay under 50% of maximum effort. If something hurts, back off. But don't stop completely. Walk, do light band work, swim, ride the bike easy. Keep the body moving without loading the things that need to heal.
The Bigger Picture

Recovery isn't sexy. There's no PR, no highlight reel, no transformation photo. But it's the part of fitness that most people skip ‚Äî and it's the part that determines whether you're still doing this in 10, 20, or 30 years.

I'd rather take a planned recovery week now than be forced into months off later because I ignored the warning signs. That's the average and active approach ‚Äî sustainable, consistent, and backed by science. Not glamorous, but effective.
If you're dealing with nagging injuries, don't just push through. And don't just stop. Find the middle ground. Use the tools that work. Let your body do what it's designed to do ‚Äî heal.

title: Game Day Taco Dip: The Only Appetizer That Matters
excerpt: The layered taco dip I grew up eating every time IU basketball was on TV. Refried beans, seasoned Greek yogurt, all the toppings, and a pile of chips. Dead simple, feeds a crowd, and it never makes it to halftime.

body.text: Some foods just hit different because of when you ate them. This taco dip is one of those for me. Every time IU basketball was on ‚Äî and if you grew up in Indiana, you know that was a big deal ‚Äî this dip was on the table. Big platter, bag of chips, the whole family parked in front of the TV. It didn't matter if we were ranked or getting blown out. The dip showed up.

I've made this for years now and it's still the first thing I think of when game day rolls around. It's not fancy. It's not trying to be. It's the kind of appetizer that a room full of people will demolish before the second quarter, and someone will always ask you for the recipe ‚Äî even though there's barely a recipe to give.
Why This One Works

I'll be honest ‚Äî most game day food is a nutritional disaster. And look, I'm not here to ruin the party. But this dip actually has some things going for it. The base is refried beans, which give you fiber and protein. The second layer is Greek yogurt mixed with taco seasoning instead of sour cream ‚Äî same tangy flavor, way better macros. And then you load it up with vegetables. You're basically eating a salad with a really good delivery system.
Is it health food? No. But it's a lot better than most of what you'll find at a watch party, and nobody is going to complain that it's "healthy." That's the sweet spot.
The Build
You need a large platter. Not a bowl ‚Äî a platter. The whole point is thin layers with maximum surface area so every chip gets a little bit of everything. Here's how it goes:

items: Layer 1: One can of refried beans, spread thin across the platter. This is the foundation.
Layer 2: Greek yogurt mixed with a packet of taco seasoning. Spread it right over the beans.
Layer 3: All the toppings ‚Äî diced tomatoes, green peppers, onions, sliced black olives, shredded cheese, and lettuce on top.
Serve with tortilla chips. That's it. That's the whole thing.

body.alt: Game day taco dip loaded with toppings and ready to serve
body.caption: Loaded up and ready for tip-off.

body.text: Make It Your Own

The beauty of this dip is that it's flexible. Want some heat? Throw some sliced jalape√±os on there. Got green onions? Slice them up and scatter them across the top. Cilantro, hot sauce, a squeeze of lime ‚Äî go for it. I've seen people add guacamole as a layer too, and I'm not mad about it.

The base stays the same ‚Äî beans, seasoned yogurt, toppings. Everything else is just personal preference. My kids pick around the olives. My wife loads up on the tomatoes. I put hot sauce on mine. Everyone gets what they want off the same platter.
The Greek Yogurt Move

If you've never swapped Greek yogurt for sour cream, this is your sign. Mixed with taco seasoning, you genuinely cannot tell the difference. It's tangy, it's creamy, and it adds protein instead of just fat. I use plain nonfat or 2% Greek yogurt. Once the taco seasoning is mixed in, nobody's asking questions. They're just eating.
Game Day Memories

There's something about food that ties you to moments. For me, this dip is Assembly Hall on a Saturday afternoon. It's my family yelling at the TV. It's fighting over the last scoop on the platter. Now I'm making it for my own family during games, and my kids are starting to associate it with the same thing. That's the kind of stuff that sticks.

It takes 15 minutes to throw together, it feeds a crowd, and it never lasts long. If you need a game day appetizer, this is it. Stop overthinking it. Spread the beans, mix the yogurt, pile on the toppings, and go watch the game.

title: Why Average & Active Exists ‚Äî And Why It's Different
excerpt: The fitness world is full of peak athletes, product pushes, and perfect lighting. This isn't that. This is real life, real fitness, and the reason average matters.

body.text: Today kicks off another social platform around fitness, health, family, food, etc. Here are the reasons this one is different than the masses.
1. Not enough real

I follow a lot of fitness influencers across multiple platforms. I have respect for each of them but have quickly found they are all peak level athletes in their youth. It is great to watch their journeys but I quickly feel defeated in my own journey.
2. Unrelatable

A lot of the current content out in the wild is unrelatable, at least for me. I find it hard to relate to pro athletes, I find it hard to relate to someone that doesn't have kids, I find it hard to relate to someone much younger, I find it hard to relate to athletes in their peak era, and I find it hard to relate to someone that has their career around fitness. As said above, I respect their journeys but they are all very hard to relate to in my current stage of life.
3. Pushing product

Once I find someone that I can relate to, over time, they start to push products. Products that make them money. Products that don't help my journey. It becomes more of an ad than actual content. That is not my goal here, my goal is to share my journey and make it accessible. I don't want to push ads as ads already exist within platforms. You don't need more ads. You need more content that matters.
4. Posting the hard

At times, the influencers push the good and not the bad. Life is hard, we need to see it all. The journey has peaks and valleys. It isn't all rainbows and sunshine. I want my content to be real and felt. I want mistakes to be shown, losses to be felt and relatable.
5. Tired of the fake

I don't like the filters, I don't like the perfect lighting. As you follow people, you realize how easily a good day, lighting, and time of the day can turn into a picture that shows extreme progress. I love progress but nothing happens fast. It takes work, consistency, and time.

Overall, I am here to share my journey, make it relatable, make it felt and interact with others on a similar path. I am not here to push ads, I am not here to push products, and I am not looking to "influence" others.

title: Macro Tracking for People Who Hate Counting
excerpt: A lazy person's guide to getting your protein, carbs, and fats roughly right without losing your mind or your enjoyment of food.

body.text: I tried strict macro tracking for about three weeks before I wanted to throw my phone into a lake. Weighing every almond? Scanning every barcode? That's not sustainable when you're also packing lunches and negotiating with a 4-year-old about eating vegetables.
The 'Close Enough' Method

Here's what I actually do: I track roughly. I know what a palm-sized portion of protein looks like. I know a fist of carbs. A thumb of fat. Is it accurate to the gram? No. Is it accurate enough to make progress? Absolutely.
My Daily Targets (Roughly)

items: Protein: 150-180g (I aim for 40g per meal, 4 times a day)
Carbs: 200-250g (more on training days, less on rest days)
Fats: 60-70g (this usually takes care of itself)
Total: ~2,200 calories

body.text: The Staples That Make It Easy
I eat roughly the same things during the week. Not because I'm boring ‚Äî because decision fatigue is real when you have kids. Here are my go-tos:

items: Breakfast: Eggs + toast or protein shake + banana
Lunch: Chicken + rice bowl or turkey wrap
Dinner: Whatever the family eats (I just adjust my portion)
Snacks: Greek yogurt, protein bar, apple + almond butter

body.text: Weekends are more flexible. We eat out, we have pizza night, we live our lives. I don't track on weekends ‚Äî I just make generally smart choices and enjoy the time with family.
The One Non-Negotiable

If there's one thing I'd tell anyone to focus on, it's protein. Hit your protein target and everything else falls into place more easily. You're less hungry, you recover better, and you maintain muscle as you age. That's the whole game.

title: Working Out With a Toddler in the Room
excerpt: Yes, it's chaos. Yes, you'll get interrupted. Here's how to get a solid workout in anyway ‚Äî tiny humans included.

body.text: Let me paint you a picture: I'm mid-squat, barbell on my back, and my 3-year-old decides this is the perfect moment to show me her drawing. Of a cat. That needs a name. Right now.
If you're a parent who trains at home, you know exactly what I'm talking about. Here's how I've learned to make it work.
Accept the Chaos

Step one: let go of the idea of an uninterrupted 45-minute session. It's not happening. Once I accepted that, I actually started enjoying the absurdity of it. My daughter does 'squats' next to me with a pool noodle. My son counts my reps (inaccurately). It's messy and kind of perfect.
Strategies That Actually Help

items: Use rest periods for kid stuff ‚Äî answer the question, fix the snack, find the toy
Pick exercises that are safe to bail on (dumbbells > barbell when kids are around)
Set up a 'kid station' nearby with coloring books, blocks, or a tablet
Keep sessions short and intense ‚Äî 25 minutes of focus beats 60 minutes of distraction
Let them participate. Kid-sized dumbbells cost $10 and buy you infinite goodwill

body.text: The Real Lesson

Working out with your kids around isn't a limitation ‚Äî it's modeling behavior. They see you prioritizing your health. They see you pushing through something hard. They see you showing up even when it's not easy. That's a lesson no amount of talking can teach.

title: Zone 2 Cardio: The Boring Workout That Adds Years
excerpt: It doesn't look impressive. It won't get you likes. But zone 2 cardio might be the single best thing you can do for your health.

body.text: Zone 2 cardio is the most boring and most important type of exercise I do. It's not sexy. There's no before-and-after transformation. But the science behind it for longevity is overwhelming.
What Is Zone 2?

Zone 2 is the intensity where you can hold a conversation but it's slightly uncomfortable. You're breathing harder but you're not gasping. For most people, that's a brisk walk, an easy jog, or a moderate bike ride. Heart rate roughly 60-70% of your max.
Why It Matters

Zone 2 training improves your mitochondrial function ‚Äî basically, how efficiently your cells produce energy. It improves insulin sensitivity, cardiovascular health, and fat metabolism. Dr. Peter Attia calls it 'the most important exercise for longevity,' and after digging into the research, I agree.
How I Fit It In

items: 3-4 times per week, 30-45 minutes each
Usually a walk with the dog or a bike ride on the weekend
Sometimes I just walk on an incline treadmill while watching a show
I wear a cheap heart rate monitor to stay in the right zone

body.text: The beauty of zone 2 is that it doesn't beat you up. You can do it every day without affecting your recovery. It's the opposite of 'no pain, no gain' ‚Äî and it's arguably more important for your long-term health than any heavy lifting session.
The Dad Walk
My favorite zone 2 session? Walking the neighborhood with my kids on their bikes. They ride, I walk fast, we all get outside. Exercise that doubles as family time? That's the sweet spot.

title: The 5AM Garage Gym: How I Built a Routine That Actually Sticks
excerpt: Everyone talks about morning routines. Here's what mine actually looks like ‚Äî the good, the bad, and the days I hit snooze three times. How I went from zero consistency to never missing a weekday workout.

body.text: I'm not going to pretend I wake up every morning fired up and ready to crush a workout. Some days, the alarm goes off at 4:55 AM and every part of me wants to stay in bed. But I get up anyway. And that's kind of the whole point.
Why 5AM?

I didn't choose 5AM because I'm a morning person. I chose it because it's the only time that's truly mine. By 6:30, the kids are up. By 7:15, we're in full breakfast-backpack-bus-stop chaos. If I don't train before the house wakes up, it's not happening.
The garage gym helps too. No commute to a gym means I roll out of bed, throw on shorts, and I'm already there. The barrier to entry is literally just standing up.
The Actual Routine
I keep it simple. Four days a week, alternating between upper and lower body. Each session is 35-45 minutes. Here's what a typical week looks like:

items: Monday: Upper body (push focus) ‚Äî bench press, overhead press, rows, curls
Tuesday: Lower body ‚Äî squats, Romanian deadlifts, lunges, calf raises
Thursday: Upper body (pull focus) ‚Äî pull-ups, dumbbell rows, face pulls, triceps
Friday: Lower body + conditioning ‚Äî deadlifts, leg press, kettlebell swings

body.text: Wednesday is a rest day or a light walk. Weekends are for family hikes, backyard play, or just resting. No guilt.
What Made It Stick
Three things changed everything for me:

items: I stopped chasing perfection. A 20-minute session beats a skipped one.
I laid out my clothes the night before. Removes one more decision.
I tracked consistency, not weight. My goal is 4 sessions per week, not a PR.

body.text: The first two weeks were brutal. But after that, it became automatic. Now it feels weird NOT to train in the morning.
The Honest Truth

I still have bad days. Last week I slept through my alarm twice. The week before, my kid was sick and I was up all night. Life happens. The difference is I don't let one missed day turn into a missed week anymore.
If you're thinking about starting a morning routine ‚Äî start smaller than you think. Even 15 minutes. The habit of showing up matters more than the workout itself.

title: Why "Good Enough" Is the Goal
excerpt: Perfectionism is the enemy of consistency. Here's why I stopped chasing optimal and started chasing sustainable ‚Äî and got better results.

body.text: For years, I'd start a fitness plan, go all-in for two or three weeks, and then crash. The plan was always too perfect ‚Äî 6 workouts a week, meal prep every Sunday, no cheat meals, sleep by 10 PM. Real life doesn't work like that.
The Shift

The turning point came when I lowered my standards. Not in a giving-up way ‚Äî in a realistic way. Instead of 6 workouts, I aimed for 3. Instead of perfect nutrition, I aimed for 'mostly good.' Instead of no junk food, I aimed for 80/20.
And something unexpected happened: I actually stuck with it. For the first time in years, I was consistent. And consistency beat intensity every single time.
The Math of 'Good Enough'

items: Perfect plan followed for 3 weeks = 18 workouts, then 0
Good enough plan followed for 12 months = 150+ workouts
Guess which one gets better results?

body.text: What 'Good Enough' Looks Like

For me, good enough means: train 3-4 times a week, eat mostly whole foods, get 7+ hours of sleep most nights, walk daily, and don't stress the rest. Some weeks are better than others. That's fine. The trend line is what matters, not any single day.
Give yourself permission to be imperfect. It's the most productive thing you'll ever do for your health.

title: My Home Gym Equipment
excerpt: A real look at every piece of equipment in my home gym ‚Äî what's worth it, what's wearing out, and how it all supports triathlon training and staying strong for the long haul.

body.text: My Home Gym Setup: Everything I Use (And What's Actually Worth It)
*Real talk about the equipment that keeps this dad moving ‚Äî no sponsorships, no BS.*

If you've ever thought about building a home gym, you've probably fallen down the rabbit hole of "ultimate setup" videos from people with $50K garage gyms and lighting rigs that belong on a film set. That's not this post.

This is what a real home gym looks like when you're a parent, you train around nap times and work calls, and you need gear that earns its square footage. I've built mine out over time, and every piece in here has to justify its spot. Here's the full rundown.
The Rack: REP Ares 2.0
This is the centerpiece. If you're only going to invest in one big piece of equipment, make it a quality rack ‚Äî and the REP Ares 2.0 has been worth every penny.

Mine came with the pull-up bar, safety straps, and a large squat area, which covers about 80% of what I need for strength training. Squats, bench press, overhead press, pull-ups, rack pulls ‚Äî it all happens here. The safety straps are a non-negotiable when you're training solo. Nobody's spotting me on my lunch break, and I'm not about to get pinned under a bar between meetings.

Here's the thing nobody talks about enough: if you're an endurance athlete, you still need to be lifting. Muscle mass doesn't just stick around ‚Äî you lose it as you age, and all that cardio volume from tri training isn't doing you any favors on the preservation front. A solid rack makes it easy to keep the big compound lifts in your routine, even during heavy training blocks. That's how you stay strong and functional for the long haul, not just the next race.
Concept 2 Rower & SkiErg
These two are the cardio backbone of my gym. If you know, you know ‚Äî Concept 2 basically wrote the book on rowing machines, and there's a reason they're everywhere.

The **rower** is my go-to for steady-state cardio, warm-ups, and those days when I need to move but my legs are toast from yesterday's squats or a long ride. It's also a full-body workout disguised as "just cardio," which is sneaky efficient when you're short on time. For triathlon training, it's a great low-impact way to build aerobic capacity without adding more run or bike volume to already tired legs.

The **SkiErg** is a different beast. It hammers your upper body and core in a way that nothing else really replicates. I use it for intervals and upper body conditioning ‚Äî and it translates surprisingly well to the swim portion of tri training. That pulling pattern and the demand on your lats and shoulders carries over more than you'd think. It also takes up almost no floor space since it mounts to the wall ‚Äî big win in a home gym.
**Worth noting:** Both of these hold their resale value like crazy. If you ever decide to move on, you'll get most of your money back. That's rare for fitness equipment.
The Hex (Trap) Bar

If I could only do one lower body movement for the rest of my life, hex bar deadlifts would be in the conversation. It's more forgiving on your lower back than a straight bar, the learning curve is way shorter, and you can load it heavy without worrying as much about form breaking down when you're fatigued.

From a longevity standpoint, this is one of the best tools in the gym. You're training your posterior chain, grip strength, and total body tension ‚Äî all things that decline with age if you don't stay on top of them. And for a dad who's been sitting at a desk all day before squeezing in a workout, the hex bar lets you pull heavy with less risk. That matters when the goal is still being able to do this stuff in your 50s, 60s, and beyond.
Kettlebells

I've got a set of kettlebells and they're some of the most versatile pieces in the gym. Swings, goblet squats, Turkish get-ups, farmer carries, cleans ‚Äî the list doesn't end. They're also perfect for those days when you've got 20 minutes and need to get after it with minimal transition time.

What I really appreciate about kettlebells is how well they build the kind of functional, durable strength that actually ages well. Hip hinges, loaded carries, single-leg work ‚Äî this is the stuff that keeps you moving well as the years add up. Not flashy, but incredibly effective.
If you're starting out, a single kettlebell in the right weight can keep you busy for months before you even think about adding another.
Adjustable Dumbbells

I'll be honest ‚Äî mine are starting to show their age. The adjustment mechanism is wearing thin, and they're on the list for an upgrade. But adjustable dumbbells are still one of the smartest purchases you can make for a home gym. They replace an entire dumbbell rack in a fraction of the space.

When they work well, they're perfect for accessory work, isolation movements, and filling in the gaps that barbells miss. Think single-arm rows, lateral raises, chest flyes ‚Äî the stuff that keeps your shoulders healthy and your stabilizers strong, especially when you're putting in big swim, bike, and run volume. Just know that the moving parts *will* wear over time, especially if you're using them hard and often. Something to factor into your budget ‚Äî they're not a buy-it-once-forever piece like a Concept 2.
70lb Slam Ball
This thing is pure therapy. Bad day at work? Slam ball. Kids tested every last nerve? Slam ball. Need to build some explosive power? Also slam ball.

At 70 pounds, it's no joke. Slam ball work builds power, core strength, and conditioning all at once. It's also one of the few pieces of equipment where you're actively encouraged to throw it as hard as you can into the ground. Very cathartic. Highly recommend.

And from a longevity perspective ‚Äî explosive power is one of the first things to go as you age. Rate of force development drops off faster than raw strength does. Keeping some power work in your routine, even just slam balls a couple times a week, is an investment in your future self.
The Treadmill

This is the newest addition to the gym ‚Äî just added it about a week ago ‚Äî and I'm already wondering why I waited so long. Nobody's posting treadmill content that goes viral. But having one in the gym means I never have an excuse to skip a run. Weather's bad? Treadmill. It's dark and icy outside? Treadmill. Need to do intervals and control the pace precisely? Treadmill.

For tri training, I can already tell this is going to get a lot of use. Structured run sessions where I need to hit specific paces, bad weather days where I'd otherwise skip ‚Äî it just removes the excuses. And the thing I'm most looking forward to is stacking a run onto the back of a bike session for brick workouts. Having it ten feet away from the trainer is going to be pretty clutch once tri season ramps up.

The other big one ‚Äî I train at 6,200 feet. Running outside at altitude with hills means my heart rate is all over the place, which makes it really hard to train in specific zones. The treadmill lets me control the terrain and the climate, keep my heart rate where it needs to be, and actually dial in my training instead of just guessing. At elevation, that kind of control matters more than most people realize.
The Bike Trainer: Wahoo + Zwift Setup

This one lives in the spare room, and it deserves its own post at some point. The Wahoo trainer paired with Zwift has been a game-changer for tri training. Being able to hop on and ride structured workouts or jump into a group ride without leaving the house is massive when you've got a family schedule to work around.

Zwift makes indoor riding way more tolerable than staring at a wall, and the structured training plans are legit. It's also nice having it in a separate room ‚Äî keeps the gym feeling like a gym and the bike space feeling like its own zone where I can lock in.
For anyone juggling family life and triathlon, an indoor setup like this isn't optional ‚Äî it's how training actually happens consistently.
The Honest Truth About Building a Home Gym

I didn't buy all of this at once. It's been built up piece by piece, usually when I found a good deal or identified a real gap in my training. The best advice I can give is: **start with what supports the training you actually do**, not the training you think you *should* do.
A rack, some free weights, and one solid cardio machine will get most people further than they think. Everything else is a bonus.

My training is built around two things: triathlon and keeping muscle on my frame for as long as possible. Those might sound like they're at odds with each other, but they're not ‚Äî you just have to be intentional. The endurance work keeps my heart and lungs healthy. The strength work keeps my body resilient, protects my joints, and makes sure I'm not just a skinny dude who can run far. Both matter if the goal is being active and capable for decades, not just for the next race.

And if you're a parent reading this ‚Äî a home gym isn't a luxury. It's logistics. It's the difference between "I'll go to the gym after bedtime" (which never happens) and actually getting it done. That's worth the investment.
*Got questions about any of this gear? Drop a comment or hit me up on Instagram. Always happy to talk shop.*

title: The Only 5 Exercises You Actually Need
excerpt: Forget the complicated routines. If you can do these five movements consistently, you're ahead of 90% of the population.

body.text: The fitness industry wants you to think you need 47 different exercises, a periodized program, and a PhD in kinesiology. You don't. If you're a parent just trying to stay healthy and functional, here are the only five movements that matter.
1. Squat

Barbell, goblet, bodyweight ‚Äî doesn't matter. Squatting keeps your legs strong, your knees healthy, and your ability to get off the floor intact as you age. I do goblet squats with a dumbbell 2x per week. Nothing fancy.
2. Hinge (Deadlift)

Picking heavy stuff off the ground. This builds your back, glutes, and hamstrings ‚Äî the muscles that protect your spine when you're lifting kids, groceries, or furniture. Romanian deadlifts with dumbbells are my go-to.
3. Push (Bench Press / Push-Ups)
Upper body pushing. Bench press, push-ups, overhead press ‚Äî pick one or rotate. This keeps your chest, shoulders, and arms strong for carrying kids, pushing strollers, and everyday life.
4. Pull (Rows / Pull-Ups)
The counterbalance to all that pushing (and all that sitting at a desk). Rows and pull-ups build the back muscles that keep your posture solid. I do dumbbell rows every upper body day.
5. Carry (Farmer's Walk)

Grab two heavy dumbbells and walk. That's it. This builds grip strength, core stability, and total body endurance. It's also the most 'real life' exercise there is ‚Äî when was the last time you carried a sleeping child plus three bags of groceries up the stairs?
The Bottom Line

Master these five movements and you're set. You don't need fancy equipment, a gym membership, or a complicated program. Just these five, done consistently, with gradual progress. That's the whole recipe.

title: Meal Prep Sunday: A Real Parent's Version
excerpt: I've got about 90 minutes on Sunday afternoon. Here's how I prep meals for the week that the whole family will actually eat.

body.text: Every meal prep guide I've seen assumes you have 4 hours, 30 containers, and zero children. Here's my version ‚Äî the one that actually works when you've got a 90-minute window while the kids are doing quiet time.
The 90-Minute Game Plan
I don't prep every meal for the week. I prep the things that, if I don't have ready, will lead me to order takeout. That means: protein, grains, and a few snacks.
What I Actually Prep

items: 2 lbs chicken breast ‚Äî seasoned and baked (used in bowls, wraps, salads all week)
A big pot of rice or quinoa
Cut vegetables ‚Äî peppers, cucumbers, cherry tomatoes
Hard-boiled eggs (a dozen)
Overnight oats for 3 mornings (oats, protein powder, milk, chia seeds in jars)

body.text: The Family Crossover

Here's the trick: most of what I prep works for the whole family. The chicken goes into the kids' quesadillas. The rice goes with their dinner. I'm not making two separate meals ‚Äî I'm making building blocks that everyone can use differently.

Dinners are still cooked fresh most nights ‚Äî usually something simple like sheet pan chicken and veggies, turkey tacos, or pasta. The prep just handles lunches and breakfasts so I'm not scrambling every morning.
My Advice

Don't try to be a meal prep influencer. You don't need 15 matching containers and a color-coded menu. Just cook some protein, cook some carbs, and cut some vegetables. That's 80% of the battle right there.
